text:
Scratch 29th of March - there’s now two new dates for your Brexit diaries:
22nd May - the day the UK will leave the EU if the Withdrawal Agreement is passed 
 12th April - if the agreement isn’t passed, Parliament has until this day to decide what happens next.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: PM asked what her second choice is if her deal doesn’t pass - she won’t say other than reiterating “I do not believe we should be revoking Article 50”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The PM strikes a very different tone from last night - Theresa May says she expressed her “frustration” but she “knows MPs are frustrated too”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Two million people have now signed a petition calling for Article 50 to be revoked & the UK to stay in the EU
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Forget 29th March or 30th June - the EU has created two new key Brexit dates
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: *IF* this happens, the jeopardy of next week will be greatly reduced - both the vote on the deal & "cliff edge" of March 29th
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: BUT it's a very fluid picture here... feels like a frank discussion between EU leaders which has opened up differences in opinion
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The latest rumour mill in Brussels: EU will offer an extension until early May which is NOT contingent on the deal passing next week... and a longer delay (until end of 2019) if the UK says it will take part in European parliament elections
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Theresa May arrives in Brussels saying she still hopes the UK will agree a Brexit deal. She will meet with President Macron & President Tusk before the summit officially starts
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Sounds like the perfect breakfast tbh
author: SophyRidgeSky

text:
Very brief statement from the PM & it’s a familiar message: 
 She’s not prepared to delay Brexit for longer than June 30th
 Scathing about MPs who will only say “what they do not want”
 The fact we are not leaving on March 29th is a matter of “great personal regret”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Theresa May: “I am not prepared to delay Brexit any further than the 30th of June”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Theresa May: “All MPs have been willing to say is what they do not want”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Theresa May: “This delay is of great personal regret for me”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The PM says she has "personally struggled" with the choice of whether to leave with no deal on March 29 - "I am passionate about delivering the result of the referendum.  But I equally passionately believe that the best way to do that is to leave in an orderly way with a deal"

text: Er, I didn’t think this needed saying but judging by my mentions it does. I’m not expressing a preference for a referendum  but saying the only way to “take no Deal off the table” as some politicians want is to a) agree a deal b) have no brexit not no Deal as your last resort.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Er, no. That’s not what I’m saying at all
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Er, it’s my point that no deal is the default position. So politicians who want to take it off the table need to be honest that the only way to do that is a) to agree a deal b) to make no Brexit the last resort.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: I’m not making a judgment between no deal/no Brexit but trying to unpick what politicians who want to take no deal “off the table” really mean
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: There are so many alliances/groupings on manoeuvres it’s very hard to predict the outcome...

text: ... partly because they are not convinced she can personally persuade enough MP, partly because they aren’t sure she will compromise on her red lines anyway...

text: From the conversations I’m having, seems like there is increasing confidence among MPs who don’t want no deal or a second referendum that a deal *can* be done across party lines. But they aren’t sure the PM will be able to deliver it...
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Brexit gridlock. EU won’t change the deal. Conservatives won’t change leader. MPs won’t change their minds on the vote. Something is desperately needed to break the impasse.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: There’s no shame in being Britain’s premier authority on the backstop
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Matt stop trying to be cool and pretending you don’t know anything about the backstop

text: If 117 Conservative MPs are prepared to vote against her in a confidence motion, it’s very hard to see how the PM’s deal passes the House. Those positions must be entrenched.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Despite a whopping 117 MPs voting against her, Theresa May now can’t be challenged for a year. Which in many ways strengthens her hand.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Supportive MPs emphasising that Theresa May got more votes in the confidence motion than the 2016 leadership contest
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: A win for Theresa May, but 117 MPs voting against her is a LOT
author: SophyRidgeSky

text:
Do you have confidence in Theresa May as PM?
Yes: 200
No: 117

author: SophyRidgeSky

text:
letters needed to trigger a confidence vote 
 votes needed to win it

But the most important number of all is the Brexit parliamentary arithmetic.... and there is no guarantee that will change with a new leader

text: Don’t worry I wasn’t criticising being tagged! Just questioning why Twitter shows things that happened hours ago rather than in chronological order
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: One of those days when I wish Twitter would stop showing me things people I follow liked several hours ago....
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Yvette Cooper makes the point that the Gvt has been insisting the vote will not be delayed and asks how people can trust what ministers are saying
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: PM on a second referendum: “I believe it would lead to a significant loss of faith in our democracy... we gave people the decision, the people decided, we should deliver on it”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Hilary Benn: The PM challenged others to be upfront but she needs to be upfront too. It was her red lines that led to the backstop
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Speaker John Bercow: I politely suggest that in any courteous environment allowing the House to have its say would be the right course to take (ie. there should be a vote on whether the vote should be delayed)
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Still no clarity as to when the vote is going to happen....
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Jeremy Corbyn: If the PM can’t negotiate a better deal “then she must make way”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Jeremy Corbyn asks the PM if she is seeking to change the deal or just obtain reassurances
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: PM says the referendum was a “defining moment” for democracy & “my duty is to honour the result of that vote.” No sign of shifting to second referendum or EEA.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Interesting. The PM says she will try and get extra reassurances on the backstop and believes she can get a majority in the House if that happens
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The PM insists: “I am in absolutely no doubt that this deal is the right one”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Laughter from the opposition benches as Theresa May makes her statement
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The PM confirms she would lose the vote “by a significant margin” if it was held tomorrow so she will defer it

text: I think if we do go to No Deal, there would be an attempt at more negotiation first

text:
Can you rule out any extension to Article 50?
Liam Fox: I think to keep Britain in the European Union would not be politically acceptable. It would not be acceptable to me
#Ridge
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Dr Liam Fox: None of us want no deal... but if politics is put ahead of the economic wellbeing of the United Kingdom we would have to walk away #Ridge
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Fox:“What I wanted was that we were outside of the single market &the customs union&outside the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice.That’s where I think we’re going to end up. If we do it slightly more slowly in order to minimise any disruption that’s fine by me" #Ridge
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Liam Fox says he's prepared to accept a longer transition period: "If we do it slightly more slowly in order to minimise any disruption that's fine by me. Having waited 40-odd years to leave the European Union, a few extra months doesn't bother me" #Ridge

text: (I tell Mary Fildes' story in my book, The Women Who Shaped Politics - it was a privilege to research) #InternationalWomenDay #IWD2018
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: the wrongs they have heaped upon our heads shall recoil on their own. They shall find their cowardly attempts to intimidate us are in vain & futile; in spite of their efforts, Still will we keep our course,stillspeak & even fight, til death shall plunge us in the shades of night"
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: But if they thought Fildes would be silenced, they were wrong. She later wrote: "The cowardly dastards who let loosetheir bloodhounds to plunge their sabres into our bosoms, and trample us undertheir horses’ hoofs, shall find, when the day of retribution arrives...
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: When Fildes refused to let go of the flag, she was bludgeoned with a truncheon. According to an eyewitness, her white dress was caught by a nail as she was dragged out of the carriage – leaving her suspended and helpless. The cavalry cut her exposed flesh with a sword.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Eye-witnesses claim the constables were specifically hunting for the audacious female speaker, Mary Fildes. She was travelling in a coach and holding a banner for the Manchester Female Reform Group when they found her.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Evidence suggests women were deliberately targeted. Reports say soldiers tried to deliberately disfigure female marchers by slashing their breasts and faces. A third of casualties were female, a vastly disproportionate number, and four women died.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Soldiers on horseback rode through the crowds, pulled out their swords and slashed. There was no chance to get away. Eleven people were killed and several hundred wounded, pierced by the soldiers’ swords or trampled underneath hooves and thousands of feet
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The local magistrates decided the organised marching was militaristic. Was this a genuine mistake or an excuse to violently break up the meeting? It's hard to see how a group that banned walking sticks for being too dangerous could be seen as a threat. They sent in armed forces.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: As the sun edged towards the middle of the sky, rows of women, men and children led by brass bands wove their way into Manchester from the surrounding towns and villages, holding banners and wearing their Sunday best.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: More anything, Fildes was ordinary. Her husband William was a journeyman manufacturer. They had two sons, John and Henry, and ran a pub. We know little else about her.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Mary Fildes was leader of the Manchester Female Reform Group, which campaigned for universal suffrage.Beyond that we know frustrating little about a woman considered so extraordinary she was given a speaking spot in front of 60,000. A revolutionary woman written out of history.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: As the sun rose over a pleasant morning, 60,000 people from across the North West made their way to St Peters Fields. Female spinners and weavers marched alongside the working men and - incredibly - a female voice was to address the crowds...
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The meeting was legal, pre-arranged and well organised. That would make no difference. One of the most shameful and bloody suppressions of a peaceful gathering was about to happen.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: On 16th August, 1819, a public meeting was called at St Peters Fields in Manchester. The city had ballooned thanks to industrialisation, but its only parliamentary representation was 2 MPs for the whole of Lancashire. The purpose of the gathering was to try and put that right
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: "Personally, I didn't vote for a long time, because I hadn't either a husband or furniture, although I was over 30," she told an interviewer. #suffragettes100 #100years
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: It's worth remembering, however, that Lilian Lenton was a respectable girl from Leicestershire who became an outlaw and ruined her health to campaign for a change in law that she did not initially benefit from.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: As soon as she was released, she started the fires again. Lenton was becoming famous for her daring escapades and great escapes. In exasperation, Leeds Police filed a report to the Home Office about the dangerous Suffragette known as the “tiny, wily, elusive Pimpernel.”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The thick rubber was forced not into her oesophagus, however, but into her windpipe. As sloppy food poured into her left lung, the young woman started violently choking. Two hours later Lilian Lenton had collapsed in her cell and nearly died from septic pneumonia.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: After one particularly daring attack where she set fire to the refreshment pavilions in Kew Gardens, she was sent to Holloway Prison and went on hunger strike. After two days the force feeding started.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Soon Lenton was carrying out audacious arson attacks."Whenever I was out of prison my object was to burn two buildings a week. No one could ignore arson, nor could they ignore young women who went about saying what I said - that whenever we saw an empty building we would burn it"
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Lenton grew up in Leicester, a quickly expanding industrial town of shoemakers and hosiers. Rather than learning to sew tights or hunting for a suitable husband, Lilian trained as a dancer. When she heard Emmeline Pankhurst in her home town, she decided on a different path.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Her life reads like a nail-biting thriller but there have been remarkably few words written about her. Not all suffragettes were middle class intellectuals, who gathered round dining tables in Kensington villas without the inconvenient distraction of working for a living.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Long-haired and strikingly beautiful, Lilian Ada Lenton told the women who greeted her: “I didn’t want to break any more windows but that I did want to burn some buildings,” so long as “it did not endanger human life other than our own.”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Lily knew passionately who she wanted to vote for: Mr Bright. If she had twenty votes, she said, she would give them all to him.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: It was a strong political conviction rather than a feminist passion for female suffrage that compelled Lily to head to the polling station
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: ..Yet this woman, who by chance was furnished with a vote, professed strong opinions and was delighted to have a chance of expressing them."
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: 1868 Englishwoman’s Review: “It is sometimes said that women, especially those of the working class, have no political opinion at all...
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: But Lily Maxwell is more than an intriguing aside in the history of female suffrage – more than a mistake on the electoral roll.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Bright: “This woman is a hard-working honest person who pays her rates…if any woman should possess a vote it is precisely such a one as she”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Maxwell knew exactly who she wanted to support: Jacob Bright the Liberal MP - a bearded radical who supported Chartism & women’s suffrage.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Next to Maxwell’s name in the electoral register is written a single word: “Woman!!”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Nobody tried to stop her. When the returning officer recorded her vote the room erupted in three cheers for Britain's first female voter.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: On the day of the vote, Maxwell made her way to the local polling station. She was escorted by a group of men, but no protection was needed
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: ... her name accidentally ended up on the electoral register.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Lily Maxwell was respectable, aspirational but ultimately unremarkable. She found herself in the history books by pure chance...
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Born in Scotland in 1801, she moved to Manchester to work as a servant. After decades of graft, she saved enough money to open a small shop
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Lily Maxwell was not well-connected, well-off, or well-educated – she was an ordinary woman who found herself in an extraordinary situation.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Written on the back of the picture are the words: “Lily – an old servant of the family.”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: In the one surviving photograph of Lily Maxwell, a doughty looking elderly woman stares into the distance just to the left of the camera.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The groping mysteriously stopped and no more was said about it. Fifty years later, Williams still believes “the response was very effective”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: After a pause, the man in question spluttered: “Gout!”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: “Oh, what has happened to you? How awful! It looks as though your foot has been really badly hurt. Have you been in a car accident?”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: The following day a male MP in his sixties hobbled into the tea-room. He immediately found himself circled by women clucking in mock-concern
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: They decided to wear their sharpest heels at the next three line whip. "Few things hurt more than stiletto heels driven into the foot.”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: There were only 29 female MPs, so it was easy to get together and work out a strategy.
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: “We were fed up about it,” she remembers. “We were Members of Parliament, we were elected, why should we be treated as feminine fodder?”
author: SophyRidgeSky

text: Women found they were being pinched–quite hard–on the bottom, arm or leg. Shirley Williams, the young Labour MP for Hitchin, had had enough
author: SophyRidgeSky
